elements.content: Direct electrolytic CO2 capture solution (e.g., bicarbonate), which bypasses the energy-intensive processes of CO2 desorption, offers a unique route for CO2 conversion to fuels or value-added chemicals. Nonprecious Ni single-atom catalysts (SACs) anchored on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) possess abundant porous structures and exhibit a high selectivity for CO production. However, these MOF-derived Ni SACs are usually synthesized by a series of complex procedures, and their abundant micropores (<2 nm) also reduce the local reactant transport in the catalysts. Herein, we report a simple one-step pyrolysis method to prepare a MOF-derived Ni SAC that can efficiently boost bicarbonate conversion to CO. The abundant mesopores around 35.4 nm significantly enhance the transport of local reactants in the catalysts. At a high current density of 100 mA/cm2, the tailored catalyst shows 67.2% Faradaic efficiency of CO, which, to the best of our knowledge, exceeds the state-of-the-art precious Ag nanoparticle catalysts reported so far. This study highlights the significance of developing nonprecious catalysts for employment in large-scale bicarbonate electrolysis conversion devices.
elements.clean_text:
Direct
electrolytic CO2 capture solution (e.g.,
bicarbonate),
which bypasses the energy-intensive processes of CO2 desorption,
offers a unique route for CO2 conversion to fuels or value-added
chemicals. Nonprecious Ni single-atom catalysts (SACs) anchored on
metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) possess abundant porous structures
and exhibit a high selectivity for CO production. However, these MOF-derived
Ni SACs are usually synthesized by a series of complex procedures,
and their abundant micropores (<2 nm) also reduce the local reactant
transport in the catalysts. Herein, we report a simple one-step pyrolysis
method to prepare a MOF-derived Ni SAC that can efficiently boost
bicarbonate conversion to CO. The abundant mesopores around 35.4 nm
significantly enhance the transport of local reactants in the catalysts.
At a high current density of 100 mA/cm2, the tailored catalyst
shows 67.2% Faradaic efficiency of CO, which, to the best of our knowledge,
exceeds the state-of-the-art precious Ag nanoparticle catalysts reported
so far. This study highlights the significance of developing nonprecious
catalysts for employment in large-scale bicarbonate electrolysis conversion
devices.

elements.content: The electrolytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) offers a promising route to convert CO2 to fuels or value-added chemicals. However, conventional CO2 electrolysis employs high-purity CO2 as the feedstock, which requires a considerable amount of energy input during the processes of CO2 capture and separation. Typically, the energy requirements during CO2 capture and separation account for >76% in a traditional postcombustion CO2 capture system. Electrolytic bicarbonate conversion to fuels or value-added chemicals (e.g., CO, formate, and C2H4) can bypass these energy-intensive processes (i.e., CO2 desorption and compression), providing an alternative approach for the future commercial application. Previous life cycle assessments confirmed that electrolytic bicarbonate conversion to CO had a 1.93 net energy ratio, much lower than that of electrolytic gaseous CO2 conversion to CO (6.19), highlighting the energy-efficient characteristics of the electrolytic bicarbonate conversion.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The
electrolytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR)
offers a promising
route to convert CO2 to fuels or
value-added chemicals. However, conventional CO2 electrolysis employs high-purity
CO2 as the feedstock, which requires a considerable amount
of energy input during the processes of CO2 capture and
separation. Typically, the energy requirements during CO2 capture and separation account for >76% in a traditional postcombustion
CO2 capture system. Electrolytic
bicarbonate conversion to fuels or value-added chemicals (e.g., CO,
formate, and C2H4) can bypass these energy-intensive
processes (i.e., CO2 desorption and compression), providing
an alternative approach for the future commercial application. Previous life cycle assessments confirmed that electrolytic bicarbonate
conversion to CO had a 1.93 net energy ratio, much lower than that
of electrolytic gaseous CO2 conversion to CO (6.19), highlighting
the energy-efficient characteristics of the electrolytic bicarbonate
conversion.

elements.content: Most studies reported so far mainly used precious Ag nanoparticles (NPs) or porous Ag foam as the catalyst to support the electroreduction of bicarbonate to CO, delivering a low selectivity and a poor economy, which prevented the current system from commercial applications. For example, Li et al. showed that an aqueous bicarbonate solution could be converted to CO with 37% Faradaic efficiency (FE) at 100 mA/cm2 using Ag NPs as the catalyst. Zhang et al. designed a porous Ag foam-based electrolytic bicarbonate conversion system and obtained 59% FE of CO (FECO) at 100 mA/cm2 under ambient pressure. However, to the best of our knowledge, nonprecious metal catalysts have never been reported that can boost electrolytic bicarbonate conversion with significant performance.
elements.clean_text:
Most studies reported
so far mainly used precious Ag nanoparticles
(NPs) or porous Ag foam as the catalyst to support the electroreduction of bicarbonate to
CO, delivering a low selectivity and a poor economy, which prevented
the current system from commercial applications. For example, Li et
al. showed that an aqueous bicarbonate solution could be converted
to CO with 37% Faradaic efficiency (FE) at 100 mA/cm2 using
Ag NPs as the catalyst. Zhang et al.
designed a porous Ag foam-based electrolytic bicarbonate conversion
system and obtained 59% FE of CO (FECO) at 100 mA/cm2 under ambient pressure. However,
to the best of our knowledge, nonprecious metal catalysts have never
been reported that can boost electrolytic bicarbonate conversion with
significant performance.

elements.content: Ni single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted great attention because of their superior selectivity toward CO production, high activity, maximum atom efficiency, and tunable coordination environment. Significant progress has been made on tailoring the coordination structure of the Ni atom, achieving nearly 100% FECO during the electrolytic gaseous CO2 conversion. For example, Wang et al. reported an axial traction strategy to optimize the electronic structure of Ni–N4. The results showed that FECO of the synthesized Ni–N4–O/C catalysts could be maintained >90% at the potential range of −0.5 to −1.1 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Zhang et al. developed a Ni–N3–C catalyst, which showed 95.6% FECO, much superior to that of the Ni–N4–C catalyst. Over the past decades, a number of carbon materials for anchoring Ni atoms were evaluated for CO2RR, such as carbon black, graphene, three-dimensional porous carbon, carbon plate, and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). MOFs, due to their abundant pore size distribution, tailorable composition, and structure, have been regarded as one of the most promising candidates to load Ni SACs. However, current MOF-derived Ni SACs are usually prepared through a series of complex steps. For example, Zhang et al. reported low-coordinate MOF-derived Ni atoms for highly selective CO2 reduction. The ZIF-8 precursor was first synthesized in methanol by hydrothermal and centrifugation and then heated to 900 °C to obtain Zn–N3–C. Subsequently, Zn–N3–C was cleaned using 1 M HCl and dispersed with Ni species to synthesize Ni–N3–C at 700 °C. Zhao et al. reported a double-solvent approach to prepare the MOF-derived Ni SACs. The initial ZIF-8 precursor was first synthesized in methanol and then dispersed with the added Ni­(NO3)2 in n-hexane. These complex procedures probably reduce the economic efficiency and increase the energy consumption.
elements.clean_text:
Ni single-atom catalysts (SACs) have
attracted great attention
because of their superior selectivity toward CO production, high activity,
maximum atom efficiency, and tunable coordination environment. Significant progress has been made on tailoring the coordination
structure of the Ni atom, achieving nearly 100% FECO during
the electrolytic gaseous CO2 conversion. For example, Wang
et al. reported an axial traction strategy to optimize the electronic
structure of Ni–N4. The results showed that FECO of the synthesized Ni–N4–O/C catalysts could be maintained >90% at the potential
range of −0.5 to −1.1 V versus the reversible hydrogen
electrode (RHE). Zhang et al. developed a Ni–N3–C
catalyst, which showed 95.6% FECO, much superior to that
of the Ni–N4–C catalyst. Over the past decades, a number of carbon materials for
anchoring Ni atoms were evaluated for CO2RR, such as carbon
black, graphene, three-dimensional porous carbon, carbon
plate, and metal–organic frameworks
(MOFs). MOFs, due to their abundant pore
size distribution, tailorable composition, and structure, have been
regarded as one of the most promising candidates to load Ni SACs.
However, current MOF-derived Ni SACs are usually prepared through
a series of complex steps. For example, Zhang
et al. reported low-coordinate MOF-derived Ni atoms for highly selective
CO2 reduction. The ZIF-8 precursor
was first synthesized in methanol by hydrothermal and centrifugation
and then heated to 900 °C to obtain Zn–N3–C.
Subsequently, Zn–N3–C was cleaned using 1
M HCl and dispersed with Ni species to synthesize Ni–N3–C at 700 °C. Zhao et al. reported a double-solvent
approach to prepare the MOF-derived Ni SACs. The initial ZIF-8 precursor was first synthesized in methanol and
then dispersed with the added Ni­(NO3)2 in n-hexane. These complex procedures probably reduce the economic
efficiency and increase the energy consumption.

elements.content: Besides, these MOF-derived Ni SACs mainly possess abundant micropores (<2 nm) to enlarge the specific surface area and active sites. Hursán et al. found that the CO2RR activity and selectivity were highly dependent on the porosity of catalysts. Their results suggested that an optimal mesoporous size of around 27 nm had the highest FECO and partial current density of CO (j CO) due to the excellent CO2 absorption and hydrophobic properties, highlighting the significance of tuning the microstructure of catalysts. In addition to the excellent CO2 absorption and hydrophobic properties, CO2 transport within catalysts is also an important factor affecting the performance of CO2RR. Notably, these micropores (<2 nm) of MOFs are much smaller than the mean free path of CO2 molecules (76 nm, at standard temperature and pressure), resulting in CO2 molecules mainly transporting through Knudsen diffusion (a,b), in which CO2 molecules collide with the wall of micropores frequently and significantly reduce the effective diffusion coefficient of CO2 molecules by orders of magnitude. This decrease leads to a low local CO2 concentration around the active sites and hence a low FECO during the electrolytic bicarbonate conversion, especially at high current densities. Therefore, adjusting the pore size of catalysts to provide both a suitable CO2 transport and a high specific surface area is important for the performance of CO2RR.
elements.clean_text:
Besides, these
MOF-derived Ni SACs mainly possess abundant micropores
(<2 nm) to enlarge the specific surface area and active sites. Hursán et al. found that the CO2RR activity and
selectivity were highly dependent on the porosity of catalysts. Their results suggested that an optimal mesoporous
size of around 27 nm had the highest FECO and partial current
density of CO (j
CO) due to the excellent
CO2 absorption and hydrophobic properties, highlighting
the significance of tuning the microstructure of catalysts. In addition
to the excellent CO2 absorption and hydrophobic properties,
CO2 transport within catalysts is also an important factor
affecting the performance of CO2RR. Notably, these micropores
(<2 nm) of MOFs are much smaller than the mean free path of CO2 molecules (76 nm, at standard temperature and pressure),
resulting in CO2 molecules mainly transporting through
Knudsen diffusion (a,b), in which CO2 molecules collide with the wall
of micropores frequently and significantly reduce the effective diffusion
coefficient of CO2 molecules by orders of magnitude. This decrease leads to a low local CO2 concentration around the active sites and hence a low FECO during the electrolytic bicarbonate conversion, especially at high
current densities. Therefore, adjusting the pore size of catalysts
to provide both a suitable CO2 transport and a high specific
surface area is important for the performance of CO2RR.

elements.content: Here, we designed an efficient MOF-derived Ni SAC to boost electrolytic bicarbonate conversion to CO using a simple one-step pyrolysis method. In addition, we introduced abundant mesopores into the prepared catalysts to increase the effective diffusion coefficient of CO2 and local CO2 concentration and simultaneously offer a high specific area. The tailored catalysts exhibited significant 67.2% FECO at 100 mA/cm2 for the electrolytic bicarbonate conversion. The results demonstrated that the tailored Ni SACs delivered a higher FECO than those achieved with most state-of-the-art precious NP electrocatalysts under the same conditions reported so far. This study offers a unique perspective for designing nonprecious catalysts for electrolytic bicarbonate conversion.
elements.clean_text:
Here, we designed an efficient MOF-derived Ni SAC to boost electrolytic
bicarbonate conversion to CO using a simple one-step pyrolysis method.
In addition, we introduced abundant mesopores into the prepared catalysts
to increase the effective diffusion coefficient of CO2 and
local CO2 concentration and simultaneously offer a high
specific area. The tailored catalysts exhibited significant 67.2%
FECO at 100 mA/cm2 for the electrolytic bicarbonate
conversion. The results demonstrated that the tailored Ni SACs delivered
a higher FECO than those achieved with most state-of-the-art
precious NP electrocatalysts under the same conditions reported so
far. This study offers a unique perspective for designing nonprecious
catalysts for electrolytic bicarbonate conversion.

elements.content: ZIF-8 [Zn­(MeIm)2] was selected as the precursor because of its high crystallinity and ultrafine porosity. Ni SACs were synthesized using previously reported high-temperature pyrolysis procedures and further optimized in this study (). The precursors and obtained Ni SACs were defined as X-Ni-ZIF and Ni/Zn-X, respectively (X represents the ratio of content of Ni and Zn during the preparation). a shows that X-Ni-ZIF possesses a rhombododecahedron structure and smooth surfaces. After the high-temperature pyrolysis, Ni/Zn-X maintained the initial rhombododecahedron structure of ZIF-8 [Zn­(MeIm)2] but showed a significant collapse on the surface. The distortion degree became more severe with the increase of Ni2+ concentration, which was probably because the added Ni2+ affected the interaction of Zn2+ and 2-methylimidazole. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis was conducted to evaluate the different microstructures of Ni/Zn-X (b–d). During the high-temperature pyrolysis, the volatilization of metallic Zn species introduced abundant micropores on the carbon materials, and the added Ni2+ species produced amounts of mesopores, confirmed by the pore volume distribution (b). c shows that the specific surface areas of Ni/Zn-0, Ni/Zn-2, Ni/Zn-4, Ni/Zn-6, and Ni/Zn-8 are 929.14, 833.06, 756.74, 735.03, and 729.49 m2/g, respectively. With the increase of the added Ni2+ species, the number of mesopores and the specific surface areas of Ni/Zn-X reduced. Furthermore, we selected two typical samples (Ni/Zn-0 and Ni/Zn-6) to evaluate their pore size distribution, as shown in d. Ni/Zn-0 mainly possessed a number of micropores (<2 nm), but Ni/Zn-6 delivered abundant mesopores (2–50 nm) and macropores (>50 nm). This difference in the microstructure of catalysts was expected to have a great effect on the performance of bicarbonate electrolysis. In addition, the surface elemental ratios of Ni/Zn-X were analyzed through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Table S1). The Ni contents of Ni/Zn-0, Ni/Zn-2, Ni/Zn-4, Ni/Zn-6, and Ni/Zn-8 were 0, 0.33, 0.51, 0.67, and 0.77 at. %, respectively. The increased Ni ratio of Ni/Zn-X exhibited that more Ni–N active sites were anchored in the catalysts, which was probably beneficial to the electrochemical performance.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
Materials Synthesis and
Characterization
ZIF-8 [Zn­(MeIm)2] was selected
as the precursor because
of its high crystallinity and ultrafine porosity. Ni SACs were
synthesized using previously reported high-temperature pyrolysis procedures and further optimized in this study (). The precursors
and obtained Ni SACs were defined as X-Ni-ZIF and
Ni/Zn-X, respectively (X represents
the ratio of content of Ni and Zn during the preparation). a shows that X-Ni-ZIF possesses a rhombododecahedron structure and smooth
surfaces. After the high-temperature pyrolysis, Ni/Zn-X maintained the initial rhombododecahedron structure of ZIF-8 [Zn­(MeIm)2] but showed a significant collapse on the surface. The distortion
degree became more severe with the increase of Ni2+ concentration,
which was probably because the added Ni2+ affected the
interaction of Zn2+ and 2-methylimidazole. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller
(BET) analysis was conducted to evaluate the different microstructures
of Ni/Zn-X (b–d). During the high-temperature pyrolysis,
the volatilization of metallic Zn species introduced abundant micropores
on the carbon materials, and the added Ni2+ species produced
amounts of mesopores, confirmed by the pore volume distribution (b).
c shows that the specific surface areas of Ni/Zn-0, Ni/Zn-2, Ni/Zn-4,
Ni/Zn-6, and Ni/Zn-8 are 929.14, 833.06, 756.74, 735.03, and 729.49
m2/g, respectively. With the increase of the added Ni2+ species, the number of mesopores and the specific surface
areas of Ni/Zn-X reduced. Furthermore, we selected
two typical samples (Ni/Zn-0 and Ni/Zn-6) to evaluate their pore size
distribution, as shown in d. Ni/Zn-0 mainly possessed a number of micropores
(<2 nm), but Ni/Zn-6 delivered abundant mesopores (2–50
nm) and macropores (>50 nm). This difference in the microstructure
of catalysts was expected to have a great effect on the performance
of bicarbonate electrolysis. In addition, the surface elemental ratios
of Ni/Zn-X were analyzed through X-ray photoelectron
spectroscopy (XPS) spectra (Table S1).
The Ni contents of Ni/Zn-0, Ni/Zn-2, Ni/Zn-4, Ni/Zn-6, and Ni/Zn-8
were 0, 0.33, 0.51, 0.67, and 0.77 at. %, respectively. The increased
Ni ratio of Ni/Zn-X exhibited that more Ni–N
active sites were anchored in the catalysts, which was probably beneficial
to the electrochemical performance.

images of the precursors (X-Ni-ZIF-8)
and the obtained Ni SACs (Ni/Zn-X). (b) N2 adsorption and desorption curves and (c) specific surface area of
Ni/Zn-X. (d) Pore size distribution of Ni/Zn-0 and
Ni/Zn-6.

elements.content: To distinguish the existential form of Ni species, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and corresponding elemental mappings of Ni/Zn-6 were recorded, confirming that Ni and N species were uniformly dispersed on the carbon materials and no Ni NPs were observed (a,b). Besides, aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF–STEM) images of Ni/Zn-6 were recorded (c). These bright spots with ∼0.2 nm atomic diameters were close to the diameter of a single Ni atom (0.21 nm), demonstrating the atomically dispersed Ni. d shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Ni/Zn-6, in which two diffraction peaks of carbon materials are located at 25.2 and 43.8°, which correspond to the graphitic (002) and (101) planes, respectively. Metallic Ni was not detected, further demonstrating the atomic form of Ni species. High-resolution Ni 2p XPS spectra for Ni/Zn-6 (e) indicated that Ni 2p3/2 binding energy was located at 855.7 eV, which was more positive than that of metallic Ni (852.6 eV), which confirmed that these Ni atoms were likely to be in positive oxidation states. f shows the N 1s XPS spectra for Ni/Zn-6, which can be divided into five subpeaks: oxidized N (404.0 eV), graphitic N (401.2 eV), pyrrolic N (400.2 eV), Ni–N (399.0 eV), and pyridinic N (398.0 eV). These abundant Ni–N species were beneficial to the performance of electrolytic bicarbonate conversion.
elements.clean_text:
To distinguish the existential
form of Ni species,
transmission
electron microscopy (TEM) images and corresponding elemental mappings
of Ni/Zn-6 were recorded, confirming that Ni and N species were uniformly
dispersed on the carbon materials and no Ni NPs were observed (a,b). Besides, aberration-corrected
high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF–STEM) images
of Ni/Zn-6 were recorded (c). These bright spots with ∼0.2 nm atomic diameters
were close to the diameter of a single Ni atom (0.21 nm), demonstrating
the atomically dispersed Ni. d shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Ni/Zn-6,
in which two diffraction peaks of carbon materials are located at
25.2 and 43.8°, which correspond to the graphitic (002) and (101)
planes, respectively. Metallic Ni was not detected, further demonstrating
the atomic form of Ni species. High-resolution Ni 2p XPS spectra for
Ni/Zn-6 (e)
indicated that Ni 2p3/2 binding energy was located at 855.7
eV, which was more positive than that of metallic Ni (852.6 eV), which
confirmed that these Ni atoms were likely to be in positive oxidation
states. f shows
the N 1s XPS spectra for Ni/Zn-6, which can be divided into five subpeaks:
oxidized N (404.0 eV), graphitic N (401.2 eV), pyrrolic N (400.2 eV),
Ni–N (399.0 eV), and pyridinic N (398.0 eV). These abundant
Ni–N species were beneficial to the performance of electrolytic
bicarbonate conversion.

elements.content: Morphological and structural characterizations of Ni/Zn-6. (a) High-resolution TEM image and (b) corresponding elemental mappings. (c) Aberration-corrected HAADF–STEM image. (d) XRD patterns. High-resolution Ni 2p (e) and N 1s (f) XPS spectra.

elements.content: a shows the FECO of Ni/Zn-X at various potentials in an H-cell (the corresponding FE of H2 is shown in Figure S1). All samples except Ni/Zn-0 delivered a high selectivity for CO production, while Ni/Zn-0 exhibited a low FECO <23% at all potentials, confirming the presence of Ni atoms was responsible for CO2RR. Ni/Zn-6 showed the highest FECO of 94% at −1.0 V versus RHE, followed by Ni/Zn-8 (89%), Ni/Zn-4 (79.3%), and Ni/Zn-2 (68.1%). Additionally, Ni/Zn-6 exhibited a high FECO >80% at a wide potential window of −0.8 to −1.3 V versus RHE. b shows that Ni/Zn-6 possesses a −18.5 mA/cm2 j CO at −1.3 V versus RHE, which was superior to those of Ni/Zn-4 (−16.1 mA/cm2), Ni/Zn-8 (−15.5 mA/cm2), Ni/Zn-2 (−9.2 mA/cm2), and Ni/Zn-0 (−2.1 mA/cm2) under the same conditions. These metrics confirmed that Ni/Zn-6 could efficiently boost electrolytic CO2 conversion to CO. To investigate the long-term stability of the prepared catalysts, Ni/Zn-6 was continuously operated at −1.0 V versus RHE for 40 h (c). The results indicated that the FECO of Ni/Zn-6 was still >84% after 40 h of continuous operation, demonstrating its durability for CO2RR.
elements.clean_text:
Electrolytic Gaseous CO2 and Bicarbonate
Conversion

a shows the FECO of Ni/Zn-X at
various potentials in an H-cell (the corresponding FE of H2 is shown in Figure S1). All samples except
Ni/Zn-0 delivered a high selectivity for CO production, while Ni/Zn-0
exhibited a low FECO <23% at all potentials, confirming
the presence of Ni atoms was responsible for CO2RR. Ni/Zn-6
showed the highest FECO of 94% at −1.0 V versus
RHE, followed by Ni/Zn-8 (89%), Ni/Zn-4 (79.3%), and Ni/Zn-2 (68.1%).
Additionally, Ni/Zn-6 exhibited a high FECO >80% at
a wide
potential window of −0.8 to −1.3 V versus RHE. b shows that Ni/Zn-6
possesses a −18.5 mA/cm2
j
CO at −1.3 V versus RHE, which was superior to those
of Ni/Zn-4 (−16.1 mA/cm2), Ni/Zn-8 (−15.5
mA/cm2), Ni/Zn-2 (−9.2 mA/cm2), and Ni/Zn-0
(−2.1 mA/cm2) under the same conditions. These metrics
confirmed that Ni/Zn-6 could efficiently boost electrolytic CO2 conversion to CO. To investigate the long-term stability
of the prepared catalysts, Ni/Zn-6 was continuously operated at −1.0
V versus RHE for 40 h (c). The results indicated that the FECO of Ni/Zn-6
was still >84% after 40 h of continuous operation, demonstrating
its
durability for CO2RR.

elements.content: (a) FECO and (b) j CO of Ni/Zn-X performed in a conventional H-cell at various potentials. (c) Long-term stability of Ni/Zn-6 performed in a conventional H-cell at −1.0 V vs RHE. (d) FECO measured during electrolysis of a 3 M KHCO3 solution at various current densities employing the zero-gap flow cell for Ag NPs-, Ni/Zn-2-, Ni/Zn-4-, Ni/Zn-6-, and Ni/Zn-8-coated GDLs without the micropore layer. (e) Cell voltage of Ni/Zn-6 and Ag NPs at various current densities during electrolytic bicarbonate conversion.

4

(a) FECO and (b) j
CO of
Ni/Zn-X performed in a conventional H-cell at various
potentials. (c) Long-term stability of Ni/Zn-6 performed in a conventional
H-cell at −1.0 V vs RHE. (d) FECO measured during
electrolysis of a 3 M KHCO3 solution at various current
densities employing the zero-gap flow cell for Ag NPs-, Ni/Zn-2-,

layer. (e) Cell voltage of Ni/Zn-6 and Ag NPs at various current densities
during electrolytic bicarbonate conversion.

elements.content: To investigate the performance of Ni/Zn-X for electrolytic bicarbonate conversion, a zero-gap flow cell with a bipolar membrane (BPM) was employed (Figure S2), and a GDL sprayed with Ag NPs was selected as the control. d shows the FECO of all samples measured during the electrolysis of a 3 M KHCO3 solution from 50 to 200 mA/cm2. Ni/Zn-6 exhibits the best activity for bicarbonate conversion and achieves the highest FECO of 52.2% at 100 mA/cm2, which is boosted by 260 and 63% compared to that of Ni/Zn-2 and Ag NPs, respectively. However, as the Ni content further increased, the FECO of Ni/Zn-8 was slightly decreased (46.2% at 100 mA/cm2). This variation was probably because the low specific surface area of Ni/Zn-8 reduced the active sites. Besides, excessive loading of Ni species could introduce Ni nanoclusters and reduce the stability of Ni SACs. As the current density increased to 200 mA/cm2, the FECO of Ni/Zn-6 decreased to 46.2% because of the enhanced activity of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Furthermore, we compared the cell voltage of Ni/Zn-6 and Ag NPs (e), which exhibited that Ni/Zn-6 had a low cell voltage at various current densities (e.g., −3.63 V, 100 mA/cm2) compared to that of Ag NPs (e.g., −3.78 V, 100 mA/cm2), demonstrating the excellent electrolytic activity of Ni/Zn-6.
elements.clean_text:
To investigate the performance of Ni/Zn-X for
electrolytic bicarbonate conversion, a zero-gap flow cell with a bipolar
membrane (BPM) was employed (Figure S2),
and a GDL sprayed with Ag NPs was selected as the control. d shows the FECO of all samples measured during the electrolysis of a 3 M
KHCO3 solution from 50 to 200 mA/cm2. Ni/Zn-6
exhibits the best activity for bicarbonate conversion and achieves
the highest FECO of 52.2% at 100 mA/cm2, which
is boosted by 260 and 63% compared to that of Ni/Zn-2 and Ag NPs,
respectively. However, as the Ni content further increased, the FECO of Ni/Zn-8 was slightly decreased (46.2% at 100 mA/cm2). This variation was probably because the low specific surface
area of Ni/Zn-8 reduced the active sites. Besides, excessive loading
of Ni species could introduce Ni nanoclusters and reduce the stability
of Ni SACs. As the current density increased to 200 mA/cm2, the FECO of Ni/Zn-6 decreased to 46.2% because of the
enhanced activity of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Furthermore,
we compared the cell voltage of Ni/Zn-6 and Ag NPs (e), which exhibited that Ni/Zn-6
had a low cell voltage at various current densities (e.g., −3.63
V, 100 mA/cm2) compared to that of Ag NPs (e.g., −3.78
V, 100 mA/cm2), demonstrating the excellent electrolytic
activity of Ni/Zn-6.

elements.content: To further enhance the performance of bicarbonate electrolysis, we introduced a tunable pore size strategy to facilitate CO2 transport in the catalyst layer (a,b). Employing a NaCl-assisted pyrolysis method, we got a new catalyst (denoted as NaCl@Ni/Zn-6) with abundant mesopores (2–50 nm) and macropores (>50 nm), confirmed by the TEM images (c,d) and BET analysis (e,f). f shows that the mesopores of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 are mainly concentrated at 35.4 nm. These introduced mesopores and macropores could enhance the effective diffusion coefficient of CO2, further enhancing the CO2 transport in the catalyst layer and electrolytic bicarbonate performance. The specific surface area of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 (611.80 m2/g) was slightly decreased compared to that of Ni/Zn-6 (735.03 m2/g) due to the reduction in the proportion of micropores in NaCl@Ni/Zn-6. Furthermore, we adjusted the NaCl concentration during pyrolysis to explore the influence of pore size distribution (Figure S3). When reducing the NaCl concentration, the specific surface area of the catalyst increased to 649.29 m2/g, but the pore size mainly concentrated on micropores <2 nm and exhibited a 45.5% FECO at 100 mA/cm2. This variation was ascribed to the abundant micropores that impended the CO2 transport within the catalyst. We enlarged the pore size of catalysts by adding more NaCl and obtained a catalyst that possessed abundant mesopores around 37.4 nm but reduced the specific surface area to 466.53 m2/g and only exhibited a 56.2% FECO at 100 mA/cm2. This decline was due to the decreased specific surface area that reduced the active sites. It can be concluded that enabling a suitable CO2 transport and simultaneously possessing a high specific surface area are both important for the performance of electrolytic bicarbonate conversion. Besides, we conducted XPS analysis and confirmed that Ni species and Ni–N species content for NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 were similar to those for Ni/Zn-6 (Figure S4), which demonstrated that the introduction of NaCl during pyrolysis probably did not destroy the active sites.
elements.clean_text:
Microstructure Optimization
and Performance
Enhancement
To further enhance the performance of bicarbonate
electrolysis, we introduced a tunable pore size strategy to facilitate
CO2 transport in the catalyst layer (a,b). Employing a NaCl-assisted pyrolysis method, we got a
new catalyst (denoted as NaCl@Ni/Zn-6) with abundant mesopores (2–50
nm) and macropores (>50 nm), confirmed by the TEM images (c,d) and BET analysis
(e,f). f shows that the
mesopores of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 are mainly concentrated at 35.4 nm. These
introduced mesopores and macropores could enhance the effective diffusion
coefficient of CO2, further enhancing the CO2 transport in the catalyst layer and electrolytic bicarbonate performance.
The specific surface area of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 (611.80 m2/g)
was slightly decreased compared to that of Ni/Zn-6 (735.03 m2/g) due to the reduction in the proportion of micropores in NaCl@Ni/Zn-6.
Furthermore, we adjusted the NaCl concentration during pyrolysis to
explore the influence of pore size distribution (Figure S3). When reducing the NaCl concentration, the specific
surface area of the catalyst increased to 649.29 m2/g,
but the pore size mainly concentrated on micropores <2 nm and exhibited
a 45.5% FECO at 100 mA/cm2. This variation was
ascribed to the abundant micropores that impended the CO2 transport within the catalyst. We enlarged the pore size of catalysts
by adding more NaCl and obtained a catalyst that possessed abundant
mesopores around 37.4 nm but reduced the specific surface area to
466.53 m2/g and only exhibited a 56.2% FECO at
100 mA/cm2. This decline was due to the decreased specific
surface area that reduced the active sites. It can be concluded that
enabling a suitable CO2 transport and simultaneously possessing
a high specific surface area are both important for the performance
of electrolytic bicarbonate conversion. Besides, we conducted XPS
analysis and confirmed that Ni species and Ni–N species content
for NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 were similar to those for Ni/Zn-6 (Figure S4), which demonstrated that the introduction of NaCl
during pyrolysis probably did not destroy the active sites.

elements.content: Illustration of (a) Knudsen diffusion and (b) bulk diffusion in porous media. TEM images of Ni/Zn-6 (c) and NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 (d). N2 adsorption and desorption curves (e) and pore diameter distribution (f) of Ni/Zn-6 and NaCl@Ni/Zn-6.
elements.clean_text:
5

Illustration
of (a) Knudsen diffusion and (b) bulk diffusion in
porous media. TEM images of Ni/Zn-6 (c) and NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 (d). N2 adsorption and desorption curves (e) and pore diameter distribution
(f) of Ni/Zn-6 and NaCl@Ni/Zn-6.

elements.content: We first explored the intrinsic activity of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 and Ni/Zn-6 in the conventional H cell during the CO2RR. NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 showed a similar FECO and j CO with Ni/Zn-6 at low overpotentials, at which the effect of local CO2 concentration is slight (a,b). However, when the potential was applied to −1.4 V versus RHE, at which the effect of local CO2 concentration is large, NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 exhibited a superior FECO (89.3%) and j CO (−28 mA/cm2) than those of Ni/Zn-6 (FECO: 64.5%; j CO: −18.3 mA/cm2). This variation in FECO and j CO could be attributed to the fact that the abundant porous structures of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 enhance the local CO2 concentration at the active sites and increase the electrolytic active surface area, which was also confirmed by the double layer capacitance analysis (c). d exhibits that the FECO of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 surpasses those of Ni/Zn-6 at various current densities. NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 achieved the highest FECO (67.2%) at the applied current density of 100 mA/cm2, which was enhanced by 28.7% compared to that of Ni/Zn-6 under the same condition. Additionally, Figure S5 exhibited that NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 had a j CO of 85.8 mA/cm2 at −4.44 V, which was much higher than that of Ni/Zn-6 (75.6 mA/cm2) under the same condition. The enhanced performance (FECO and j CO) was probably attributed to the increased CO2 mass transfer within the catalysts and the enhanced local CO2 concentration around active sites. Furthermore, the comparison of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 with other reported state-of-the-art precious Ag-based catalysts in bicarbonate electrolysis performance is summarized in e and Table S2. The results showed that the FECO of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 in our bicarbonate electrolysis cell exceeded or was comparable to recent results from the literature under the same condition. Notably, precious Ag-based catalysts have been employed in all these cases. Li et al. generated tunable syngas ranging from 2.5 to 7, but the highest FECO obtained using Ag NPs was only 28%. Zhang et al. further designed a 500 μm buffer layer between porous Ag foam and Nafion membrane to inhibit the HER activity, which obtained a 71% FECO at 100 mA/cm2. The use of Ag-based catalysts during bicarbonate electrolysis led to a huge burden on the commercial application. As a result, the designed microstructure of the catalyst (NaCl@Ni/Zn-6) can promote reactant mass transport, which enhances the local reactant concentration around the active sites and increases the electrochemical performance. The prepared Ni SAC, with an abundant mesoporous structure and a large specific surface area, as a rare example of nonprecious catalysts employed in bicarbonate electrolysis, offers a promising route to promote this technology to commercial applications.

and Ni/Zn-6
in the conventional H cell during the CO2RR. NaCl@Ni/Zn-6
showed a similar FECO and j

to −1.4 V versus RHE, at which the effect of local CO2 concentration is large, NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 exhibited a superior FECO (89.3%) and j

the increased CO2 mass transfer within the catalysts and
the enhanced local CO2 concentration around active sites.
Furthermore, the comparison of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 with other reported state-of-the-art
precious Ag-based catalysts in bicarbonate electrolysis performance
is summarized in e and Table S2. The results showed that
the FECO of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 in our bicarbonate electrolysis
cell exceeded or was comparable to recent results from the literature
under the same condition. Notably, precious Ag-based catalysts have
been employed in all these cases. Li et al. generated tunable syngas
ranging from 2.5 to 7, but the highest FECO obtained using
Ag NPs was only 28%. Zhang et al. further
designed a 500 μm buffer layer between porous Ag foam and Nafion
membrane to inhibit the HER activity, which obtained a 71% FECO at 100 mA/cm2. The
use of Ag-based catalysts during bicarbonate electrolysis led to a

microstructure of the catalyst (NaCl@Ni/Zn-6) can promote reactant
mass transport, which enhances the local reactant concentration around
the active sites and increases the electrochemical performance. The
prepared Ni SAC, with an abundant mesoporous structure and a large
specific surface area, as a rare example of nonprecious catalysts
employed in bicarbonate electrolysis, offers a promising route to
promote this technology to commercial applications.

elements.content: (a) FECO, (b) j CO, and (c) double layer capacitance analysis of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 and Ni/Zn-6 performed in a conventional H-cell. (d) FECO was measured during electrolysis of a 3 M KHCO3 solution at various current densities employing the zero-gap flow cell for NaCl@Ni/Zn-6- and Ni/Zn-6-coated GDLs without the micropore layer. (e) Bicarbonate electrolysis performance of NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 and the state-of-the-art precious Ag-based catalysts. (Blue: Ag NPs; green: Ag NPs; purple: porous Ag foam; pink: Ag foam; light blue: Ag NPs; and light purple: Ag NPs).

elements.content: In summary, we designed a new MOF-derived Ni SAC through a one-step method and showed how to tailor the pore size distribution of catalysts to boost electrolytic bicarbonate conversion to CO with a high FECO in this study. The prepared NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 with abundant porous structures showed a high FECO of 67.2% at 100 mA/cm2 for bicarbonate electrolysis. The performance metrics are higher than those of previous reports of bicarbonate-to-CO systems using precious Ag NPs catalysts reported so far. We offered a unique way to enhance the mass transfer of CO2 in catalysts by enlarging the mesopores and macropores of catalysts. These results confirmed the potential of achieving high FECO at high current densities (>100 mA/cm2) by employing nonprecious metal catalysts in the zero-gap flow cells.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In summary, we designed
a new MOF-derived Ni SAC through a one-step
method and showed how to tailor the pore size distribution of catalysts
to boost electrolytic bicarbonate conversion to CO with a high FECO in this study. The prepared NaCl@Ni/Zn-6 with abundant porous
structures showed a high FECO of 67.2% at 100 mA/cm2 for bicarbonate electrolysis. The performance metrics are
higher than those of previous reports of bicarbonate-to-CO systems
using precious Ag NPs catalysts reported so far. We offered a unique
way to enhance the mass transfer of CO2 in catalysts by
enlarging the mesopores and macropores of catalysts. These results
confirmed the potential of achieving high FECO at high
current densities (>100 mA/cm2) by employing nonprecious
metal catalysts in the zero-gap flow cells.

elements.content: All chemicals were directly purchased from Kelong (Chengdu, China) and used without further processing. MOF-derived Ni SACs were synthesized using previously reported high-temperature pyrolysis procedures and further optimized in this study. 2 mM Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and 2 mM Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 30 mL of methanol. The solution was stirred for 30 min (800 rpm). 16 mM 2-methylimidazole was added to another 30 mL of methanol solution and then stirred for 30 min (800 rpm). These solutions were mixed together and placed at ambient temperature for 24 h. Then, the mixed solution was centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 rpm and washed with methanol several times to remove the possible impurities. The obtained solid was dried at 80 °C overnight in a vacuum drying oven. The dried solid was heated to 1000 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min and maintained at 1000 °C for 4 h under a N2 atmosphere in the tube furnace (SKG08123K-610, Zhonghuan Electric Furnace Co., LTD, Tianjin, China). After cooling down to room temperature, the solid was washed using 1 M hydrochloric acid (80 °C, 12 h) to remove the Ni nanoparticles. The final solid was denoted as Ni/Zn-X (X = 0, 2, 4, 6, and 8), in which X represents the ratio of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section
MOF-Derived
Ni SAC Synthesis
All
chemicals were directly purchased from Kelong (Chengdu, China) and
used without further processing. MOF-derived Ni SACs were synthesized
using previously reported high-temperature pyrolysis procedures and
further optimized in this study. 2 mM
Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and 2 mM Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 30 mL
of methanol. The solution was stirred for 30 min (800 rpm). 16 mM
2-methylimidazole was added to another 30 mL of methanol solution
and then stirred for 30 min (800 rpm). These solutions were mixed
together and placed at ambient temperature for 24 h. Then, the mixed
solution was centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 rpm and washed with
methanol several times to remove the possible impurities. The obtained
solid was dried at 80 °C overnight in a vacuum drying oven. The
dried solid was heated to 1000 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min
and maintained at 1000 °C for 4 h under a N2 atmosphere
in the tube furnace (SKG08123K-610, Zhonghuan Electric Furnace Co.,
LTD, Tianjin, China). After cooling down to room temperature, the
solid was washed using 1 M hydrochloric acid (80 °C, 12 h) to
remove the Ni nanoparticles. The final solid was denoted as Ni/Zn-X (X = 0, 2, 4, 6, and 8), in which X represents the ratio of Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O.

elements.content: The prepared catalysts (16 mg) were dispersed in a mixed solution [8 mL of ethanol and 80 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt %)] and then sonicated for 30 min to obtain a uniform ink. Carbon cloth (WOS1009, CeTech, Taiwan, China) was washed with deionized water and ethanol several times to remove the purities before use. Then, the catalyst ink was sprayed on the carbon cloth using a spray gun toward a catalyst concentration of 2 mg/cm2.
elements.clean_text:
Electrode Preparation
The prepared
catalysts (16 mg) were dispersed in a mixed solution [8 mL of ethanol
and 80 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt %)] and then sonicated for
30 min to obtain a uniform ink. Carbon cloth (WOS1009, CeTech, Taiwan,
China) was washed with deionized water and ethanol several times to
remove the purities before use. Then, the catalyst ink was sprayed
on the carbon cloth using a spray gun toward a catalyst concentration
of 2 mg/cm2.

elements.content: In the conventional H-cell test, a cation exchange membrane (UltrexCMI-7000, Membranes International Inc., Ringwood, New Jersey, USA) was selected to separate the cathodic and anodic chambers. A Ag/AgCl electrode saturated with KCl and a Pt foil electrode were chosen as the reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. The prepared Ni/Zn-X on the carbon cloth was held using an electrode holder, as the working electrode. Two chambers were filled with 50 mL of KHCO3 (0.1 M) saturated with CO2 (99.999%, >30 min) before tests. Electrochemical measurements were conducted using an electrochemical workstation (ParSTAT MC, Princeton, New Jersey, USA). To collect the FE of the products, the working electrode was held at a constant potential for 20 min, and the rate of the CO2 gas at the inlet was set at 30 sccm using a flow controller (D07-19B, Sevenstar, Beijing, China). In N2-saturated KHCO3 solution (0.1 M), cyclic voltammetry data were collected from −0.2 to −0.3 V versus Ag/AgCl with scan rates of 10, 12, 14, 16, and 18 mV/s to measure the electrochemical surface area of the prepared catalysts. Besides, all potentials measured against a Ag/AgCl electrode (saturated with KCl) were converted to the RHE using E ( v s R H E ) = E ( v s A g / A g C l ) + 0.197 + 0.0591 × p H
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical
Measurements
In the
conventional H-cell test, a cation exchange membrane (UltrexCMI-7000,
Membranes International Inc., Ringwood, New Jersey, USA) was selected
to separate the cathodic and anodic chambers. A Ag/AgCl electrode
saturated with KCl and a Pt foil electrode were chosen as the reference
electrode and counter electrode, respectively. The prepared Ni/Zn-X on the carbon cloth was held using an electrode holder,
as the working electrode. Two chambers were filled with 50 mL of KHCO3 (0.1 M) saturated with CO2 (99.999%, >30 min)
before tests. Electrochemical measurements were conducted using an
electrochemical workstation (ParSTAT MC, Princeton, New Jersey, USA).
To collect the FE of the products, the working electrode was held
at a constant potential for 20 min, and the rate of the CO2 gas at the inlet was set at 30 sccm using a flow controller (D07-19B,
Sevenstar, Beijing, China). In N2-saturated KHCO3 solution (0.1 M), cyclic voltammetry data were collected from −0.2
to −0.3 V versus Ag/AgCl with scan rates of 10, 12, 14, 16,
and 18 mV/s to measure the electrochemical surface area of the prepared
catalysts. Besides, all potentials measured against a Ag/AgCl electrode
(saturated with KCl) were converted to the RHE using

elements.content: In the zero-gap flow cell test, Ni foam (2.5 × 2.5 cm2) and Ni/Zn-X catalysts sprayed on a carbon cloth were used as the anode and cathode, respectively. A BPM (FBM-PK, FuMA-Tech, Bietigheim-Bissingen, Germany) was used to separate the cathodic and anodic chambers. KOH solution (1 M) and KHCO3 solution (3 M) were supplied to the anode and cathode at a rate of 20 mL/min using a peristaltic pump (BT100-1F, Ditron Electronic Technology Co., Ltd., Baoding, China).
elements.clean_text:
In the zero-gap flow cell test, Ni
foam (2.5 × 2.5 cm2) and Ni/Zn-X catalysts
sprayed on a carbon cloth were used as the anode and cathode, respectively.
A BPM (FBM-PK, FuMA-Tech, Bietigheim-Bissingen, Germany) was used
to separate the cathodic and anodic chambers. KOH solution (1 M) and
KHCO3 solution (3 M) were supplied to the anode and cathode
at a rate of 20 mL/min using a peristaltic pump (BT100-1F, Ditron
Electronic Technology Co., Ltd., Baoding, China).

elements.content: Collected gaseous products were injected into a gas chromatograph (GC; GC-2030, Shimadzu, Japan) to quantify and calculate the FE of CO and H2 after electrolysis. The partial current density (j i) and FE of products were calculated as follows, respectively j i = j t o t a l × n i z i F / Q × 100 % F E = j i / j t o t a l × 100 % where z i is the number of electrons transferred to products, F is the Faradaic constant (96,485 C/mol), n i (mol) is the mole of products, Q (C) is the charge quantity, and j total is the total current density.

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were captured using a scanning electron microscope (4800, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan). TEM images were taken using a Tecnai G2 F20 microscope (FEI, Hillsboro, USA) operated at 200 kV. Aberration-corrected HAADF–STEM images were collected using a JEM ARM 200F (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) operated at 200 kV. XRD patterns were recorded on a D8 X-ray diffractometer (Brucker, Karlsruhe, Germany). XPS spectra were collected on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, Waltham, USA). BET measurements were carried out on a TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics, Atlanta, USA) analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Material Characterizations
Scanning
electron microscopy (SEM) images were captured using a scanning electron
microscope (4800, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan). TEM images were taken using
a Tecnai G2 F20 microscope (FEI, Hillsboro, USA) operated at 200 kV.
Aberration-corrected HAADF–STEM images were collected using
a JEM ARM 200F (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) operated at 200 kV. XRD patterns
were recorded on a D8 X-ray diffractometer (Brucker, Karlsruhe, Germany).
XPS spectra were collected on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Thermo
Fisher, Waltham, USA). BET measurements were carried out on a TriStar
II 3020 (Micromeritics, Atlanta, USA) analyzer.

metadata.title:
MOF-Derived
Ni Single-Atom
Catalyst with Abundant
Mesopores for Efficient Mass Transport in Electrolytic Bicarbonate
Conversion
